And were then scituate lyinge and beinge in the libertie of the Clinke aforesaid in the said parish of St Saviours in Southwark aforesaid in the said Countie of Surrey The which said two Messuages or Tenementes then were made or converted into one Messauge All which premisses the the said Leonard Bilson then had & held with & amongst divers other thinges by the said Lease and demise of the said Reverend father in God Thomas then & yett Bisshop of Winchester for divers yeares then enduringe To be had To be had: in display script and holden to the said Phillip Henslowe his executors administrators and assignes from the feast of St Michaell the Archangell then last past before the date of the said last mencioned Indenture vnto the end and Terme of Twentie yeares from thence next ensuinge and fullie to be compleate and ended vnder the yearlie Rente of ffive poundes of lawfull money of England thereby reserved to be paid to the said Leonard Bilson his executors and assignes during the said Terme of Twentie yeares at the ffeast of the Nativitie of our Lord God the Annunciacion of the blessed Virgine St Marie the Nativitie of St Iohn Baptist and St Michaell the Archangell by eaven and equall porcions. As in and by the said mencioned Indenture amongst divers other Convenauntes grauntes Articles and agreementes therein conteyned more fullie and more at large it doth and maye appeare By vertue By vertue: in display script of all which said severall leases demises assignementes and grauntes. He the saide Phillip Henslowe into all and singular the said messuages or Tenementes and premisses with all and singular theire and everie of theire rightes members and appurtenaunces entred and was thereof and of everie parte and parcell thereof lawfullie possessed accordinglie And the said Phillip Henslowe being thereof so possessed He the said Phillip Henslowe did in and vpon the sixte daye of Ianuarie nowe last past make & declare his last will and Testament in wrytinge and thereof did constitute and appoynte the said Agnes Henslowe his sole and onlie executrixe; and afterwardes he the said Phillip Henslowe died. By and after whose decease the said Agnes Henslow made probate of the same Will in due course of Lawe and tooke vpon her the due execucion thereof. By virtue whereof shee the said Agnes Henslowe nowe standeth and is lawfullie possessed of all and singular the sayde Messuages or Tenementes and all other the premisses with the appurtenaunces duringe all the Residue of the sayd seuerall Termes of yeares in the said severall Indentures & deed poll mencioned which are yett to come and unexpresed and of all the said Indentures and deed poll before mencioned and everie parte of them Nowe this indenture Nowe this Indenture : in display script further witnesseth That the said Agnes Henslowe for and in consideracon of a Competent some of lawfull money of England to her in hand payd by the said Gregorie ffrancklyn Drewe Stapley and Iohn Hamond before the ensealinge and deliverie of theise presentes. And also for divers other good Cawses and Consideracons her the said Agnes Henslowe therevnto specaillie movinge, Hath graunted bargayned and sold assigned and sett ouer. And by theis presents doth graunte bargayne and sell assigne and sett ouer vnto the said Gregorie ffrancklyn Drewe Stapley and Iohn Hamond all and singular the said messauages Wharffes profittes and premisses of what nature qualitie or condicion soever the same be of and everie parte and parcell thereof With all and singular theire and everie of theire rightes members and appurtenaunces before mencioned mente or intended to be demised assigned or conveyed to the said Phillip Henslowe by the before mencioned Indentures and deed poll and everie of them. And all the estate rightes tithe and interest severall Termes of yeares in the said severall Indentures and deed poll and everie of them before mencioned which are yett to come and vnexpired challendge clayme and demaund whatsoever of her the said Agnes Henslowe in and to the same and in and to euerie parte and parcell thereof and the Reversion and Reversions of the said Premisses and of everie parte and parcell thereof. And all rents reserved vpon any Lease demise or graunte made either by the said Phillip Henslowe or by any other Assignes of the said originall leases or any of them Together with all and singular the before mencioned Indentures and deed poll and all other leases Assignmentes deedes wrytinges & evidences touchinge or concerninge the said premisses or any parte or parcell thereof To haue and To haue and: in display script to hold All and singular the said Messuages Wharffs proffites and premisses of what nature qualitie or condicion soever the same be of and everieeach and everie and everie: for each and everie parte and parcell thereof before in and by theis presentes graunted bargayned and sould or mencioned mente or intended to be graunted bargayned or sould with all and singular theire and everie of theire rights members and appurtenaunces whatsoever. And all the estate right titthe and interest serverall Termes of yeares before mencioned which are yett to come and vnexpired challendge clayme. and demaund whatsoever of her the said Agnes Henslowe in and to the same and in and to everie parte and parcell thereof, And the Revercion and Reverciions of the said premisses and of everie parte and parcell thereof. And all Rentes reserved vpon any lease demise or graunte made either by the said Phillip Henslowe or by any other Assignee of the said Originall leases or any of them Together also with all and singular the said Indentures and Deed Poll and all other leases assignmentes deedes wrytinges and evidences touchinge or conconceringeconcerninge conconceringe: for concerningethe said premisses or any parte or parcell thereof to them the said Gregorie ffrancklyn Drewe Stapley and Iohn Hammond theire executors administrators and assignes in as large ample and beneficiall manner and forme to all intents constructions and purposes as shee the said Agnes Henslowe maye might should or ought to haue held occupied or enioyed the same if theis presents had never beene had nor made and without any accoumpt or any other matter or thinge whatsoever to be rendered on and by them the said Gregorie ffranklin Drewe Stapley and Iohn Hammond theire executors administrators or assignes to her the said Agnes Henslowe her executors or administrators for the same. In wittnes In wittnes: in display script whereof the parties aforesaid to theis presente Indentures interchangeably haue putt theire handes and seales the daye and yeare first above wrytten whereof…wrytten: There are three tags attached to the indenture, but the signing and sealing were not executed. &c

James Russell appears as a waterman in the petition (DCA: MS I, Article 17) to Lord Howard. The original lease to Russell is now DCA: Muniments, Series 1, Group 101. Russell had mortgaged the lease for £100 to Cuthbert Hackett, of London, dyer, 18 September 1602 (DCA: Muniments, Series 1, Group 128). The assignment to Henslowe is now DCA: Muniments, Series 1, Group 129. A list, dated 1602, of 'The tenantes of JEmes Russelles LEacE' appears in the Diary (177V). If the charge brought against Henslowe of keeping houses of ill-fame was well founded, the property in question was no doubt that mentioned in this lease. Winchester Place in Southwark , which was under the jurisdiction of the bishop, was notorious on this account, as appears, for instance, from the phrase ' goose of Winchester' in Troilus and Cressida (Act V, scene 10). The Fool's Head and the James' Head were distinct, being the names of the two original tenements. In the Diary we find an undated account belonging apparently to 1593 'ffor tremynge of the ffolles head' (1T 8), and a subsequent entry 'bowght the Jemes is head the 24 of aguste 1595 for—xxx li.' (8V 14). They may have been houses similar to those mentioned above.

head.title: Privy Council Order to Sir James Campbell, Lord Mayor, and JPs for Middlesex and Surrey

ab.note:
5 An ordre from the Lords
the 14th Aprill 1630 for suppressing of playes & other meetings

div.ab:
In regard of the greate apprehensione and appearance of the increase of ye Sciknes , and for that it is conceiued, that Assemblies & meetings of people for sporte & pleasure, may bee agreate meanes to spread ye same, Theire Lordshipps, haue thought fitt & ordered that aswell the Lord Maior of London , as the Iustices of peace of Middlesex & Surrey , doe take stricte & effectuall ordre to prohibite & suppresse, all Meetings & stage playes Bearebaytings, Tvmbling dancing on ye Ropes, shewes, or scights presented in howses and all other Concourse and Meetings whatsoeuer for Pastime as aforesaied, And also all Assemblies
of the Inhabitants of seuerall Counties at ye Common halls of London pretended for continuance of accquaintance, and all extraordinary assemblies of people at Tavernes or ellce where, And hereof all Magistrates whome yt may concerne, are required to take notice, & see this ordre executed without faile/
Extractr William Beecher

body.head: f 92v (13 December) ( Petition by queen of Bohemia's players for licence to perform)

note.ref: Queene of Bohemias Players for leaue to exercise the

div.ab:
A petition of the King & Queene of Bohemia's Players for leaue to exercise their quality beeing restrayned by ye Iustices theraboutes. Answered (vizt.) His Maiestie is graciously pleased that the petitioners haue free liberty to exercise their quality of playing without restraint; any former Act of prohibition to ye contrary notwithstanding./
Dec .13. 1630 1630: underlined

ab.note: A warrant for suppressing of stage playes &c.

div.ab: Haueing receiued order from the Lords &c in regard of the great appearaunce & apprehension of the increase of the sicknesse to cause all stage playes & all other Assemblyes for sports or pastimes to bee prohibited & suppressed, Theis are to pray & require you to take effectuall order that their Lordships Order therin bee duly obserued & put in execution by all those that are vnder your subordination. And for soe doeing Theis shall bee your warrant. Aprill 17. 1630. 1630: underlined To Sir H. Herbert./
Memorandum the like was warraunt was sent to Gabriell Marsch for ye suppressing of Bear & bull baitinges

head.title: Tatham, Knavery in All Trades

div.ab: third. Gentlemen, has any of you seen the Play of Harry the eight?
fourth. Many years ago I did.
fifth. And so did I.
third. 'Tis rarely set forth they say.
first . Gentlemen as I'm a Christian I ought to speak, I know and you cannot but all know, that if the Turk come into England once 'twill be the worse for the whole state of Christendom.
third. Let him come, we have Jews enough to entertain him. But sir, they say 'tis done rarely well.
fourth. I cannot believe it, 'tis impossible they should do any thing so well as I have seen things done.
fifth. When Taylor, Lewen and Pollard were alive.
fourth. Did you not know Benfield, and Swautted? SwauttedSwanston: for Swanston (?)
fifth. Did I not know 'em? Yes, and hum'd them off a hundred times.
fourth. But did you know Mat Smith, Elis Worth, and Fowler at the Fortune?

fifth. Yes, and I will tell you by a good token; Fowler you know
know know: also printed as a catch word at the foot of sig D4v was appointed for the conquering parts, and it being given out he was to play the Part of a great Captain and mighty Warriour, drew much Company; the Play began, and ended with his Valour; but at the end of the Fourth Act he laid so heavily about him, that some Mutes who stood for Souldiers, fell down as they were dead e're he had toucht their trembling Targets; so he brandisht his Sword & made his Exit; ne're minding to bring off his dead men; which they perceiving, crauld into the Tyreing house, at which, Fowler grew angry, and told 'em, Dogs you should have laine there till you had been fetcht off; and so they crauld out again, which gave the People such an occasion of Laughter, they cry'd that again, that again, that again.

fourth. I but what d'ye call him was the man; he plaid the devil in Doctor Faustus, and a fellow in the Gallery throwing a Tobacco-Pipe at him; I hope to see thee (quoth He) e're long as bad as I am, what's that quoth the fellow? the Son of a Whore quoth He.
Omnes. Ha, ha, ha.
first. You talk of your Players, I am for the Fencers, there are none living now like old Bradshaw, old Batty, Chatterton, and Ned Gibs.
